text: When it comes to acquisitions, the time to start thinking about an M&A strategy is hopefully when you don't need one. And the best strategy that I could give a founder is to have a really strong offense in building their company. And when founders start their businesses, they don't usually set out to start a company to sell it to another business. They start it to be an enduring independent standalone company. And if you have that path, then you'll have the upper hand in absolutely every single M&A conversation because you have a viable alternative, which is do nothing, stay the course, you don't have to sell.
speaker: Julia Schottenstein
context: Lenny asks Julia for advice for founders currently thinking about M&A acquisitions and how to be most successful. Julia explains that the best time to think about M&A strategy is when you don't desperately need it - having a strong independent business path gives you negotiating power. She emphasizes that founders should focus first on building a strong company that could succeed independently, as this creates optionality and leverage in any acquisition discussions.
text_ko: 인수(acquisitions)에 관해서라면, M&A 전략(M&A strategy)을 생각하기 시작해야 할 시점은 운 좋게도 사실 그 전략이 필요하지 않을 때예요. 창업자에게 제가 드릴 수 있는 최고의 전략은 회사를 키우는 데 있어 정말 강한 공격 전략(offense)을 갖추는 거예요. 창업자들이 보통 회사를 시작할 때 다른 회사에 팔기 위해 시작하지는 않아요. 대개는 독립적이고 오래 지속되는 단독 기업(standalone)을 만들기 위해 시작하죠. 그런 길을 가지고 있다면 모든 M&A 대화에서 훨씬 우위를 점해요. 현실적인 대안, 즉 가만히 있어도 되고 현재 노선을 유지하면 되고 굳이 팔 필요가 없다는 선택지가 있기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 说到收购这事儿，最好是在你还不需要的时候就开始考虑并购(M&A)策略。我给创始人的最佳建议就是，把重点放在把自己公司做强上。创始人刚开始创业的时候，一般也不是为了卖给别人才开公司的，而是想做一家能长久发展的独立公司。如果你走的是这条路，那在任何并购谈判中你都能占上风，因为你有个很靠谱的选择——什么都不做，继续按原来的路走，不一定非得卖。
text_es: Cuando se trata de adquisiciones, lo ideal es empezar a pensar en una estrategia de M&A cuando no la necesitas. Y el mejor consejo que le puedo dar a un fundador es que se enfoque en construir su empresa con mucha fuerza. Porque cuando los fundadores arrancan sus negocios, normalmente no lo hacen pensando en vendérsela a otra empresa. Lo hacen para crear una compañía independiente que perdure. Y si tienes ese rumbo, entonces vas a tener todas las de ganar en cualquier conversación de M&A, porque tienes una alternativa real: no hacer nada, seguir tu camino, no tienes por qué vender.

text: M&A is always about creating plan Bs. And the way I would think about it is for any one company, there's only ever two to three buyers that find what you're building to be extremely strategic. And the strategy that I would do in how do you get noticed is I would figure out the area that you bring a competitive advantage. And I would inflict pain on that potential buyer. Make it impossible for them to not notice you because that's when they're going to have their ears perk up and say, 'Well, what's going on with this company?'
speaker: Julia Schottenstein
context: Julia is explaining her M&A strategy for founders looking to get acquired. She describes how to get noticed by potential acquirers - by identifying your competitive advantage and strategically competing with them in a way that forces them to pay attention. The concept of 'inflicting pain' means competing effectively enough that the potential buyer can't ignore your impact on their business, which makes them more likely to consider acquiring you.
text_ko: 인수합병(M&A)은 언제나 플랜 B(plan B)를 만드는 문제예요. 제 생각에는, 한 회사가 만드는 걸 진짜 전략적으로 보는 인수자(buyer)는 많아야 두세 곳뿐이에요. 눈에 띄게 하려면 제가 할 전략은 회사가 경쟁 우위(competitive advantage)를 가진 영역을 찾아내는 거예요. 그리고 그 잠재 인수자에게 압박을 가해서 못 본 척할 수 없게 만들 거예요. 그래야 그들이 귀를 쫑긋 세우고 "이 회사에 무슨 일이 있지?"라고 하게 되거든요.
text_zh: 并购其实就是给自己留后路嘛。我是这么看的，对于任何一家公司来说，真正觉得你在做的事情对他们有战略价值的买家，也就那么两三个。那怎么让他们注意到你呢？我的策略是，你得先搞清楚自己的竞争优势在哪儿，然后就在这个领域给潜在买家制造点压力。让他们没办法忽视你的存在，这样他们才会竖起耳朵想："咦，这家公司到底在搞什么名堂？"
text_es: Las fusiones y adquisiciones siempre se tratan de crear planes B. Y yo lo veo así: para cualquier empresa, solo hay dos o tres compradores que realmente van a ver lo que estás construyendo como algo súper estratégico. Y la estrategia que yo usaría para que te noten es identificar el área donde tienes ventaja competitiva. Y ahí les vas a meter presión a ese posible comprador. Hacerles imposible que no te noten, porque ahí es cuando se van a despertar y van a decir: "¿Qué está pasando con esta empresa?"

text: The really important piece here is you want to do that in a way that's still friendly and open. I see a lot of founders get this wrong and they prematurely will shut down a conversation or they won't talk to an incumbent or a potential future buyer because they take too competitive of a stance. But that's a mistake because M&A is all about creating plan Bs and you don't want to shut that door down prematurely because you don't know if you can really go the distance and be an independent company.
speaker: Julia Schottenstein
context: Julia continues explaining her M&A strategy, emphasizing the balance between competition and collaboration. After discussing how to 'inflict pain' on potential buyers, she warns that founders often make the mistake of being too aggressive or competitive, which closes off acquisition opportunities. She stresses that M&A is about creating backup plans (plan Bs) and maintaining optionality, since most companies can't successfully remain independent forever.
vocabulary_highlights: take too competitive of a stance
text_ko: 여기서 정말 중요한 건 그걸 여전히 우호적이고 개방적인 방식으로 해야 한다는 거예요. 많은 창업자들이 이걸 잘못해서 너무 경쟁적으로 나오다가 대화를 너무 일찍 닫거나 기존 업체나 잠재적 인수자와 아예 얘기조차 안 하는 경우를 많이 봐요. 그런데 그건 실수예요. 인수합병(M&A)은 플랜 B(plan B)를 만들어 두는 일이니까요. 독립 회사로 끝까지 갈 수 있을지 모르는 상황에서 그 가능성을 일찍 차버리면 안 돼요.
text_zh: 这里最关键的一点是，你要用一种友好开放的方式来处理这些事情。我看到很多创始人在这方面搞错了，他们会过早地中断对话，或者不愿意跟现有的公司或者潜在的收购方聊，因为他们把姿态摆得太有竞争性了。但这其实是个错误，因为并购(M&A)说到底就是给自己留后路，你不能过早地把这扇门关死，因为你也不知道自己到底能不能坚持到底，真的做成一家独立的公司。
text_es: Lo que realmente importa aquí es que hagas esto manteniendo un tono amigable y abierto. Veo que muchos fundadores la riegan en esto y terminan cortando conversaciones de manera prematura o no quieren hablar con empresas establecidas o posibles compradores porque se ponen muy competitivos. Pero eso es un error porque las fusiones y adquisiciones se tratan de crear planes B, y no quieres cerrar esa puerta antes de tiempo porque no sabes si realmente vas a poder llegar hasta el final como empresa independiente.

text: And when dbt was first getting started, you would hear a lot from companies, I don't understand, what's so special about dbt? We have a SQL templating tool at our company, we built one in-house. Like this is really straightforward and simple and it's true like dbt is really simple, but that is the power of it. So our founders, Tristan, Drew and Connor, they had a belief that the people who do data analysis work, that really work closely with their business stakeholders should also be the ones to contribute to creating clean data assets in production because that data prep work is a necessary prerequisite for any analysis that you do.
speaker: Julia Schottenstein
context: Lenny asks Julia what dbt did right to become the default standard in the modern data stack. Julia explains one key factor was their focus on power through simplicity. She describes how other companies initially dismissed dbt as too simple since they had built similar tools in-house. However, dbt's founders believed that data analysts who work with business stakeholders should be empowered to create clean production data, not just data engineers, and dbt's simplicity made this possible.
text_ko: dbt가 막 시작할 때 많은 회사에서 “dbt가 뭐가 그렇게 특별해요? 우리도 SQL 템플릿 도구(SQL templating tool)가 있고, 사내에서 직접 만들었어요”라는 반응이 많았어요. 사실 dbt가 정말 단순하다는 건 맞아요. 그런데 바로 그 단순함이 강점이에요. 그래서 창업자 Tristan, Drew, Connor는 데이터 분석(data analysis) 업무를 실제로 비즈니스 이해관계자들과 밀접하게 하는 사람들이 운영 환경(production)에서 깨끗한 데이터 자산(data assets)을 만드는 데 기여해야 한다고 믿었어요. 데이터 준비(data prep) 작업은 어떤 분석을 하든 반드시 선행돼야 하는 일이니까요.
text_zh: 当初dbt刚起步的时候，经常会听到一些公司说，我搞不懂，dbt有什么特别的？我们公司有自己的SQL模板工具，是我们内部开发的。这东西看起来很直接很简单嘛。确实，dbt就是很简单，但这恰恰就是它的厉害之处。所以我们的创始人Tristan、Drew和Connor，他们有个理念，就是那些做数据分析的人，那些真正和业务方紧密合作的人，他们也应该参与到生产环境中干净数据资产的创建工作中来，因为数据预处理(data prep)是你做任何分析之前都必须要做的事情。
text_es: Y cuando dbt apenas estaba empezando, escuchabas mucho de las empresas: "No entiendo, ¿qué tiene de especial dbt? Nosotros tenemos una herramienta de plantillas SQL (SQL templating tool) en nuestra empresa, la desarrollamos internamente. Esto es súper sencillo y directo." Y es cierto, dbt es realmente simple, pero ahí está su poder. Entonces nuestros fundadores, Tristan, Drew y Connor, tenían la convicción de que las personas que hacen análisis de datos, que realmente trabajan de cerca con los stakeholders del negocio, también deberían ser las que contribuyan a crear activos de datos limpios en producción, porque ese trabajo de preparación de datos es un prerequisito necesario para cualquier análisis que hagas.

text: So dbt is really easy to get started with at your company with reduced friction. We're building a product that people, so they talk about it, they want to share it both at their organization and with other companies. Other companies get started with dbt again with reduced friction. We now get to see this really diverse set of use cases for dbt across company sizes, across industries and it allows us to build a truly horizontal company. As our company grows, we get to invest back into our community and our product and the flywheel begins to spin faster.
speaker: Julia Schottenstein
context: Julia explains how dbt's open source strategy created powerful network effects and a flywheel for growth. She describes how dbt's low friction, easy-to-start approach led users to evangelizing the product both within their companies and to other organizations. This organic sharing created a diverse user base across different company sizes and industries, allowing dbt to become a horizontal platform. The growing user base then enabled more investment in community and product, accelerating the growth flywheel.
text_ko: 그래서 dbt는 회사에서 시작하기가 정말 쉬워요 — 진입 장벽이 낮아져서요(reduced friction). 저희는 사람들이 자연스럽게 이야기하고 조직 안팎에서 공유하고 싶어하는 제품을 만들고 있어요. 다른 회사들도 마찬가지로 진입 장벽이 낮아져서 다시 dbt를 도입하게 되고요. 덕분에 회사 규모나 업종을 가리지 않고 정말 다양한 dbt 활용 사례를 보게 됐고, 그걸 바탕으로 진정한 수평형 회사(horizontal company)를 만들어갈 수 있어요. 회사가 커질수록 저희는 커뮤니티와 제품에 더 투자할 수 있고, 플라이휠(flywheel)이 더 빨리 굴러가기 시작해요.
text_zh: 所以dbt在公司里特别容易上手，没什么阻力。我们做的这个产品呢，大家用了都爱聊，愿意在自己公司内部分享，也愿意跟其他公司分享。其他公司看到了也很容易就开始用dbt，同样没什么门槛。现在我们能看到dbt的使用场景特别丰富，各种规模的公司都在用，各个行业都有，这让我们能做成一个真正的横向平台型公司。随着我们公司越做越大，我们就能把更多资源投回到社区和产品上，这个飞轮(flywheel)就转得越来越快了。
text_es: Entonces dbt es súper fácil de implementar en tu empresa sin tantas complicaciones. Estamos creando un producto que a la gente le encanta, hablan de él, lo quieren compartir tanto en su organización como con otras empresas. Otras empresas empiezan a usar dbt también sin tanto rollo. Ahora vemos una variedad increíble de casos de uso para dbt en empresas de todos los tamaños, de todas las industrias, y eso nos permite construir una empresa verdaderamente horizontal. Conforme nuestra empresa crece, podemos reinvertir en nuestra comunidad y nuestro producto, y el volante (flywheel) empieza a girar más rápido.

text: So we recently codified our philosophy when it comes to competition. And I'll give Nick Handel the founder of Transform who led this exercise at dbt Labs. But we really have three pillars when it comes to competition. So the first is hold true to our vision. We're really excited about the path and the journey that we're going on at dbt Labs and we don't want the distraction. So occasionally you'll have competitors maybe throw shade or throw stones, but most of that is just noise.
speaker: Julia Schottenstein
context: Lenny asks Julia how to think about competition and how much energy to put into watching competitors. Julia explains dbt's three-pillar philosophy for handling competition. The first pillar is staying focused on their own vision despite competitive distractions. She mentions that competitors sometimes 'throw shade' (criticize publicly) but emphasizes treating this as noise rather than letting it derail their strategic focus.
text_ko: 그래서 최근에 경쟁에 대한 우리 철학을 문서화했어요. 이 작업을 이끈 dbt Labs의 Transform 창업자 닉 핸델(Nick Handel)에게 공을 돌리고 싶어요. 경쟁에 관해서는 사실 세 가지 기둥이 있어요. 첫째는 우리 비전에 충실하는 거예요. dbt Labs에서 우리가 가는 길과 여정에 대해 정말 기대하고 있고, 그런 부분에서 산만해지고 싶지 않아요. 가끔 경쟁자들이 비난을 하거나 흠집을 내려 할 수도 있지만, 대부분은 그냥 잡음이에요.
text_zh: 我们最近把竞争理念给整理成文了。这个工作是我们Transform的创始人Nick Handel在dbt Labs主导的。我们对竞争有三个核心原则。第一个就是坚持我们的愿景。我们对dbt Labs现在走的路和发展方向特别兴奋，不想被其他事情分散注意力。偶尔会有竞争对手说三道四或者使绊子，但大部分都是噪音而已。
text_es: Entonces hace poco definimos nuestra filosofía respecto a la competencia. Y le doy el crédito a Nick Handel, el fundador de Transform, que lideró este ejercicio en dbt Labs. Pero básicamente tenemos tres pilares cuando se trata de competencia. El primero es mantenernos fieles a nuestra visión. Estamos súper emocionados con el rumbo y el camino que estamos tomando en dbt Labs y no queremos distracciones. Entonces de vez en cuando vas a tener competidores que tal vez te tiren hate o te critiquen, pero la mayoría de eso es puro ruido.

text: It's really like an all hands on deck conversation. Pricing is so cross-cutting because it's a finance discussion as well. You're modeling out things in spreadsheets and figuring out how that might impact the business. But you can't just solve these problems in spreadsheets. You have to go talk to customers, test the waters, understand where people's appetites are and sussing that out is really hard.
speaker: Julia Schottenstein
context: Lenny asks Julia about dbt's first-ever pricing change and what that process was like. Julia describes how pricing decisions require collaboration across multiple departments - it's not just a product decision but involves finance, customer research, and business modeling. She emphasizes that while spreadsheet analysis is important, you must also conduct customer interviews to understand willingness to pay, though getting honest feedback about pricing from customers is challenging.
text_ko: 정말 전사적으로 다 같이 나서서 논의해야 하는 얘기예요. 프라이싱(pricing)은 여러 부서를 가로지르는 문제라 재무적인 부분과도 연결되어 있어요. 스프레드시트(spreadsheet)로 모델을 만들어 그게 비즈니스에 어떤 영향을 줄지 계산해보지만, 스프레드시트만으로는 해결할 수 없어요. 결국 직접 고객을 만나 얘기해보고, 반응을 테스트해서 사람들이 어느 정도 수요가 있는지 파악해야 하는데, 그걸 알아내는 게 정말 어려워요.
text_zh: 这就像是全公司都要参与的讨论。定价这个事儿特别复杂，因为它涉及到财务层面。你得在表格里建模型，算算对业务会有什么影响。但光靠表格是解决不了问题的，你必须去跟客户聊，试试水，摸清楚大家的接受度在哪儿——这真的很难搞清楚。
text_es: Es realmente como cuando necesitas a todo el equipo trabajando en algo. Los precios tocan todas las áreas porque también es un tema financiero. Estás modelando cosas en hojas de cálculo y viendo cómo puede impactar el negocio. Pero no puedes resolver estos problemas solo con números en Excel. Tienes que hablar con los clientes, tantear el terreno (test the waters), entender qué tan dispuestos están a pagar y descifrar eso es súper complicado.
